imagine if you want to call your friend Andrew but you don't have his phone number you can't just tell the phone
company call Andrew they don't know what to do with that right so you need to
look up what Andrews phone number is your device doesn't know so you might go
look at Andrews different social media profiles you might google Andrews name you might

he doesn't know that nobody knows right and so it is with dns actually you'll
see shortly that dns also has an authoritative record for what the IP address for a given domain is now let's
say you open up your browser on your laptop and you type in WWE example comm into the browser's address bar and you
hit enter what happens well that's actually not the full URL there's an invisible dot at the end of the address
and that invisible dot will become important shortly the first thing that
your your computer is going to do is perform a forward lookup afford lookup
is the name of the DNS operation that resolves a URL a domain name into an IP
address and so issues this Ford lookup to something called a DNS resolver that
is usually run by your ISP okay and the DNS resolver is your agent the dns
resolver is going to help you answer this question without forcing you to go and ask any other servers any other
entities so the dns resolver doesn't know either it know what w-what the IP address for
www.example.com is but it says I know I'm gonna ask the root server the root
server contains the records for the dot at the very very end of the URL because
the URL is going to be resolved backwards so to ask the root servers hey where are the records what is the
address for example.com and the root server says you know what I don't know but I know who has the records for all

gives it back now all of these records have what's called a TTL field TTL stands for time to live and the time to
live tells the DNS resolver hey do not keep this record in your cache for more
than this amount of seconds so the TTL is 60 seconds the DNS resolver knows
that after 60 seconds I'm going to evict this address record for this domain and
I'm gonna go through the process all over again because otherwise it could be stuck indefinitely with an outdated
record right and consequently this is why when you go and change a record in
your hosted zone in your domain registry it takes a little while to propagate right you see that message that's like DNS propagation could take up to 48
hours that's because one of the default TTL s is one hour and if you if you wait
for one hour to propagate tear after tear after tear that adds up and you just don't know how long it'll take so to err on the side of safety your
domain registrar will tell you wait up to wait for up to 24 to 48 hours before you call us on the phone right so that's

HCP interactions with servers that are secured using TLS so first off a little

it's a very weird way to say it but SSL stands for Secure Sockets Layer and this
was a security protocol created by Netscape to enable commerce in the we early days of the Internet and since SSL
was so critical to conducting business transactions on the Internet they changed the name to TLS to avoid any
sort of concerns with Netscape being acquired by AOL bla bla bla right so we
have TLS and these days almost nobody uses SSL it's just TLS one Oh through one two so you might wonder well what
what exactly does HTTP get you and there are two categories of benefits the first
is that you get a bunch of functional benefits specifically identity
confidentiality and integrity identity means that you know that the server is who you think it is otherwise they can
change the IP address it out from under you they can point the DNS record to a different IP address and you're not sure you're talking to the same server
anymore right if it's if you're talking to Bank of America com you want to know who you're sending your
bank information to right so the first thing that HTTPS does is let you know
with a high level of confidence who you're talking to and I'll show you how shortly the second thing is
confidentiality once the HTTPS channel has been established the HTTP traffic
that goes over that channel is now confidential that means a third party cannot arbitrarily snoop on that traffic
they can't read what's going on the messages to them appear to be garbage and they also cannot tamper with these
messages so that they can kind of deny your ability to communicate with the other party and that's the integrity
part what even if you don't care about any of these things you should still care about HTTPS because there are two
critical non-functional capabilities that it grants you the first is just user trust a lot of people have been
trained to not enter their credit card information unless they see a padlock icon in the browser and that's that's
actually pretty good advice right you should not be sending your credit card information over plaintext so
a you know it creates user trust a lot of users will just not use your site or will not conduct financial transactions
unless they see that it's over HTTPS even if they understand exactly what that means the second is that search
engine optimization now takes HTTPS into consideration so your search rank on Google will actually vary depending on
whether your site has been secured with TLS now let's take a look at how exactly
this works on the Left we have our browser and on the right we have the
server which with the IP address that we fetched from performing a dns resolution
right and to start again we have example comm oh sorry we're over that we have
the IP address so the first thing is that we need to secure this TCP session
and so the client sends a special message literally called client hello
and client hello also includes a couple of other things that clues a timestamp and includes a bunch of random numbers that we're going to use later and
includes the set of cipher suites these are the cipher algorithms that the
clients browser is capable of the of using the server takes a look at all
this data and it says ok I can use one or more of those cipher algorithms I'm
gonna choose the one that I want to use and I'm also going to send back to the client my timestamp my random number and the
x.509 SSL certificate that contains the server's identity and this is the
certificate that you can get issued from Amazon certificate manager automatically upon receiving the server hello the
client is now going to authenticate their certificate and how it does this
is that each certificate it has some claims about the subject so for example it's saying this is example.com but it
also it has a very critical claim which is an issuer which is who issued this certificate and that certificate also
has an issuer and on and on and on until you get to what's called the root certificate authority and so what this
does is create a chain of certificates on the client machine and if any one of those certificates is invalid if it's
expired the signature doesn't check out then the client fails the authentication process
and it says something fishy is going on here I cannot trust this particular transaction and so it bails on the HTTP
session session establishment but if everything checks out then the client
and the server or the client sends back a pre master key to the server okay with
the pre master key now both the client and the server have three effectively random numbers the pre master key the
client random bits and the server random bits and using a fancy mathematical function it combines all this stuff and
it gets what's called a session key and both of these with these three inputs it gets the same output so it now it has a
session key and it uses this session key to perform symmetric encryption on all
traffic going across the session from here on out and now anybody who does not
have the session key does not know what information is being transferred it does know that information is being
transferred but if it cannot read any of it with me so far okay so that's SSL in
a nutshell now I also mention that we needed to just to create a cloud front
distribution in order to get SSL working but what is cloud front cloud front is a
content delivery network that's capable of caching and serving requests to your
website at a variety at a variety of locations across the world here's a map
of all of the cloud front cache locations in total there are 180 points
of presence these are just physical locations where we can cache your data 169 of these are what we call edge
locations in other words they're not associated with one of the AWS regions the other 11 are called regional caches
as their name implies they are associated with one of the AWS regions and cloud front is part of the Amazon
global network the Amazon global network is the most sophisticated and extensive
public infrastructure network available it has the largest footprint of any public infrastructure network and it
consists of all of the AWS regions their availability zones and all of the cloud
front edge locations that I've just met you can learn more about the Amazon global network at infrastructure dot AWS
there's some cool visualization tools so what does the CDN do for us now let's
say that we're here in Toronto today and we're gonna communicate with our server
in Oklahoma City right in the bottom left if I issue a request from a client
in Toronto that request you know knowing DNS knowing as I sell all this stuff now
it's still going over tcp/ip which means that that request is going to be subject
to routing behaviors from all sorts of public infrastructure providers right
it's gonna be subject to that for the ISP provider that I'm choosing the mobile network operator so this request
may make a number of hops before it gets to the destination and what this means
is that for my users the latency and the variance of that latency is going to be
high the more hops the higher it is in fact this visualization oversimplifies it it's very normal to have your packets
go through 20 or more hops in order to get to your destination as matters a lot because each hop there's physical
distance that that packet is going over a fiber connection somewhere and then once it gets to the router it has to be
parsed it has to be routed so that's all time and this matters you know anybody here a gamer and you can play video
games you know you don't want to play on a server that has really high ping right cuz that's just not fun you want to play
on a server with really good ping but you don't get really good ping unless your operators have optimized the route
that your packets take and a CDN can help you do that what does the CDN look like what does the picture look like
when we have a CDN as part of this equation again our originating location is Toronto if we have a CDN edged
location nearby our packet goes there I mean while the packet is in transit to
the CDN it may take several hops so you know the para - is a simplification but at that point it's on the Amazon global
network that packet is now traversing across custom hardware dedicated fiber
lines spare bandwidth capacity custom routing infrastructure in other words that pack
is gonna get there as quickly as possible so here's the logical diagram
of what happens when you build a cloud front distribution you're actually saying look all over the world Tokyo New
York Madrid London in these edge locations create a little folder for me and anytime there's a customer near that
endpoint route that customer to that endpoint and then fetch the resources from my origin my static assets my
index.html might my style is that CSS my JavaScript bundles fetch those from the
origin the static s3 bucket and then once you fetch them cache them away hold
on to them they're static assets they won't change right and serve them out of that edge location to this customer and
other future customers that ask for that same resource serve it right out of the cache don't go to the origin and that
means that you're not even making the round-trip back to the origin you're serving the content at maximum speed
from an edge location co-located with your customer now the astute among you might notice
where that when with cat when we deploy a cache we actually have a cache
invalidation problem right what happens if you go and change index.html and a
customer hits the Tokyo server the Tokyo services yeah I don't need to go consult the origin I have the answer here you go
it's an old answer right and this is one of the trade-offs that you get with a
CDN you have a cache coherency problem but there are common strategies to deal
with this for example if you're building applications with any sort of JavaScript
framework you know if you inspect the output directory that all the static assets have the common names for humans
to read but then they have some grid attached to them which means that that static asset has a
fundamentally different URL so when your clients request the static asset if
they're requesting olsat well that's cashed and that's correct but if they request a new static asset that's a cache miss at the CDN and the
CDN will now go fetch that asset from the origin so it's not a free lunch
there are problems to work around with caching validation and cache coherency but there are commonly tested well
understood solutions for cache busting the second thing I want to point out about cloud front is that it supports a
programmatic API that allows you to invalidate the cache that means instead of waiting for this client to say hey I
want this resource oh I don't have it let me go ask for it you can proactively say hey I know there's been a change on
my back-end at the origin I want to flush all of the cache data across my entire cloud front
distribution and you can do that with the click of a button now everything I
described with cloud front works primarily for HTTP but again those of
you are gamers you know that your favorite games don't just work over HTTP they don't typically work over HTTP at
all they work over TCP or UDP and if you want to route if you want to have what
is the effective equivalent of a CDN for arbitrary TCP UDP WebSocket traffic you
need a slightly different service it's called AWS global accelerator I don't have a lot of time to go into depth but
the fundamentals are the same again it's finding an edge location so that you can traverse across the Amazon global
network for as much of the duration as possible especially if you're building video games this is going to streamline
the ping times that your customers experience so happy to talk more about that offline and with that that is all I
